articles.headline: Yemen’s Despair on Full Display in ‘Ruined’ City
articles.snippet: No place in the beleaguered country has suffered as severely as Aden, a blockaded port city captive to deadly street fighting for the better part of a month.
articles.abstract: No place in the beleaguered country has suffered as severely as Aden, a blockaded port city captive to deadly street fighting for the better part of a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADEN, Yemen — Rooftop snipers have emptied the streets of this dusty seaside city and swelled its hospitals and morgues.
articles.byline: By Fathi Bin-Lazrq and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Questions About Airbnb’s Responsibility After Attack by Dog
articles.snippet: While Airbnb has begun offering secondary insurance coverage to its hosts in the United States, guests in other countries may have to cover the costs of any accidents themselves.
articles.abstract: While Airbnb has begun offering secondary insurance coverage to its hosts in the United States, guests in other countries may have to cover the costs of any accidents themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Airbnb’s short and startling ride to global ubiquity, it has delighted many people. Hosts can rent rooms or their entire home and use the income to avoid having a day job, to make ends meet or to get into the bed-and-breakfast business without bothering with local licensing rules or all the usual red tape.

articles.headline: G.M. Deems Steering Issue Unworthy of Recall
articles.snippet: General Motors’ handling of a recent problem in its vehicles sheds new light on what the company and regulators consider an issue worthy of a recall.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ handling of a recent problem in its vehicles sheds new light on what the company and regulators consider an issue worthy of a recall.
articles.lead_paragraph: As awareness grew last year of General Motors’ failure to disclose a dangerous defect in millions of older cars, its executives had a clear message for the public: Safety was G.M.’s first priority.

articles.headline: Middle Class, but Feeling Economically Insecure
articles.snippet: A perspective that was once characterized by comfort and optimism has increasingly been overlaid with stress and anxiety.
articles.abstract: A perspective that was once characterized by comfort and optimism has increasingly been overlaid with stress and anxiety.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not only what you have, but how you feel.

articles.headline: The Young Hopes of Kenya, Laid in the Grave
articles.snippet: The heavy weight of loss was evident in the Kenyan families who began to bury the students who were killed by the Shabab at Garissa University College.
articles.abstract: The heavy weight of loss was evident in the Kenyan families who began to bury the students who were killed by the Shabab at Garissa University College.
articles.lead_paragraph: GATUNDU, Kenya — The cars swung out onto Thika Road, one by one.

articles.headline: Do-It-All Era Ending as G.E. Returns to Core
articles.snippet: General Electric’s announcement is a stark recognition that it has become harder for financial services businesses to make big profits in the postfinancial crisis environment.
articles.abstract: General Electric’s announcement is a stark recognition that it has become harder for financial services businesses to make big profits in the postfinancial crisis environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric’s announcement on Friday that it will sell off most of GE Capital, its once-sprawling finance unit, is both another nail in the coffin of the American conglomerate and a stark recognition that it has become harder for financial services businesses to make big profits in the postfinancial crisis environment of tighter regulation and lower risk.

articles.headline: Hedge-Fund Magnate Robert Mercer Emerges as a Generous Backer of Cruz
articles.snippet: The reclusive Long Islander who made his fortune using computers to outsmart the stock market is a key early bankroller of Senator Ted Cruz’s fast campaign start.
articles.abstract: The reclusive Long Islander who made his fortune using computers to outsmart the stock market is a key early bankroller of Senator Ted Cruz’s fast campaign start.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two men share a passion for unbridled markets, concerns about the Internal Revenue Service and a skeptical view of climate change.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Risky Moves in the Game of Life Insurance
articles.snippet: Some insurance companies’ complex, and mostly hidden, maneuvers to increase profits for shareholders may end up costing taxpayers and policyholders.
articles.abstract: Some insurance companies’ complex, and mostly hidden, maneuvers to increase profits for shareholders may end up costing taxpayers and policyholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July 2013, the smart money was saying the company that runs the Caesars and Harrah’s casinos would go bankrupt, when a big investor, Apollo Global Management, offered a lifeline: It was willing to pump millions of dollars into the parent of the struggling casino company.

articles.headline: Obama Meets Raúl Castro, Making History
articles.snippet: President Obama came to the Summit of the Americas in Panama determined to defuse a generations-old regional dispute over Cuba’s exclusion from the meeting.
articles.abstract: President Obama came to the Summit of the Americas in Panama determined to defuse a generations-old regional dispute over Cuba’s exclusion from the meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANAMA — President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba met here Saturday in the first face-to-face discussion between the leaders of the two countries in a half-century.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Randal C. Archibold

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Weighs How to Recast Ties to Obama
articles.snippet: As Mrs. Clinton approaches her 2016 presidential campaign, she and her advisers are trying to determine the risks of aligning too closely with President Obama, and of keeping him at a distance.
articles.abstract: As Mrs. Clinton approaches her 2016 presidential campaign, she and her advisers are trying to determine the risks of aligning too closely with President Obama, and of keeping him at a distance.
articles.lead_paragraph: He defeated her in a grueling Democratic nomination battle. Then she pursued his agenda across the world as secretary of state. Now, the delicate relationship between Hillary Rodham Clinton and President Obama is about to get even more complicated.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Empty Ebola Clinics in Liberia Are Seen as Misstep in U.S. Relief Effort
articles.snippet: After the U.S. spent hundreds of millions of dollars and deployed nearly 3,000 troops, only 28 Ebola patients have been treated at the 11 centers built by the American military in Liberia.
articles.abstract: After the U.S. spent hundreds of millions of dollars and deployed nearly 3,000 troops, only 28 Ebola patients have been treated at the 11 centers built by the American military in Liberia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — As bodies littered the streets and the sick lay dying in front of overwhelmed clinics last year, President Obama ordered the largest  American intervention ever in a global health crisis, hoping to stem the deadliest Ebola epidemic in history.

articles.headline: The Case Against Gay Marriage: Top Law Firms Won’t Touch It
articles.snippet: The arguments against same-sex marriage to be presented at the Supreme Court have been left to members of lower-profile firms.
articles.abstract: The arguments against same-sex marriage to be presented at the Supreme Court have been left to members of lower-profile firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The stacks of Supreme Court briefs filed on both sides of the same-sex marriage cases to be heard this month are roughly the same height. But they are nonetheless lopsided: There are no major law firms urging the justices to rule against gay marriage.

articles.headline: House That Wouldn’t Budge (or Float Away) Faces a Last Stand
articles.snippet: After its owner refused to vacate, a 600-square-foot bungalow that is now abutted by taller commercial buildings has become a shrine to defiance.
articles.abstract: After its owner refused to vacate, a 600-square-foot bungalow that is now abutted by taller commercial buildings has become a shrine to defiance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Asuman Engin and her family, making their first visit to Seattle recently from their home in San Diego, spotted what may be the most famous tiny house in the world as they were coming over a nearby bridge.

articles.headline: Amazon, Google and More Are Drawn to Home Services Market
articles.snippet: Bringing the efficiency of the web to common household tasks has opened a new door to the home services industry, which is estimated to be worth more than $800 billion.
articles.abstract: Bringing the efficiency of the web to common household tasks has opened a new door to the home services industry, which is estimated to be worth more than $800 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The installation of Deborah David’s new kitchen faucet was a $145 job. But it lies at the heart of an expanding $400 billion commercial war.

articles.headline: Blackstone’s Deal With G.E. Highlights Its Real Estate Holdings
articles.snippet: The transaction shows how the power on Wall Street has shifted since the financial crisis from risk-averse investment banks to asset managers.
articles.abstract: The transaction shows how the power on Wall Street has shifted since the financial crisis from risk-averse investment banks to asset managers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Blackstone’s top executives fan out across the globe, pitching their services at elite gatherings of investors, they invariably tell the crowd: Hope you guys like this hotel, because we own it.

articles.headline: Working, but Needing Public Assistance Anyway
articles.snippet: A University of California study finds that taxpayer money is effectively subsidizing employers who pay at or around the minimum wage.
articles.abstract: A University of California study finds that taxpayer money is effectively subsidizing employers who pay at or around the minimum wage.
articles.lead_paragraph: A home health care worker in Durham, N.C.; a McDonald’s cashier in Chicago; a bank teller in New York; an adjunct professor in Maywood, Ill. They are all evidence of an improving economy, because they are working and not among the steadily declining ranks of the unemployed.

articles.headline: Wall Street Banks’ Mutual Funds Can Lag on Returns
articles.snippet: Most funds run by the four largest Wall Street banks in the business have underperformed their basic benchmarks over the last 10 years, according to a Morningstar analysis.
articles.abstract: Most funds run by the four largest Wall Street banks in the business have underperformed their basic benchmarks over the last 10 years, according to a Morningstar analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing challenges on all fronts, Wall Street banks are pinning some of their hopes on a relatively simple business opportunity: creating mutual funds for ordinary savers.

articles.headline: Coachella Festival Fends Off Rivals With Fresh Acts and Eye on Style
articles.snippet: Now in its 16th year, Coachella has firmly settled into the formula that has made it the nation’s premier pop festival.
articles.abstract: Now in its 16th year, Coachella has firmly settled into the formula that has made it the nation’s premier pop festival.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — As the gates to Coachella opened Friday and thousands of fans began to stream across the grass of the Empire Polo Club here, Paul Tollett, the impresario behind the music festival, was as calm as could be.

articles.headline: Terrorism Case Renews Debate Over Drone Hits
articles.snippet: An American once considered a possible target to be killed in Pakistan is in custody in the United States, bolstering an argument that it is feasible to capture terrorism suspects, even in remote parts of the world.
articles.abstract: An American once considered a possible target to be killed in Pakistan is in custody in the United States, bolstering an argument that it is feasible to capture terrorism suspects, even in remote parts of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Texas-born man suspected of being an operative for Al Qaeda stood before a federal judge in Brooklyn this month. Two years earlier, his government debated whether he should be killed by a drone strike in Pakistan.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: At the Head of the Pack, HBO Shows the Way Forward
articles.snippet: HBO has restocked its content cupboard with hits; launched HBO Now, its stand-alone streaming service; and appears to be taking a victory lap.
articles.abstract: HBO has restocked its content cupboard with hits; launched HBO Now, its stand-alone streaming service; and appears to be taking a victory lap.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2007, just as Tony Soprano faded to black, HBO fell into a deep slump. Forgettable shows like “John From Cincinnati” and “Tell Me You Love Me” did poorly, each lasting only a season. Its content cupboard was bare, and rival TV executives openly referred to the cable network as “HB-Over.”
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Starts to Detail Rationale for Run as Campaign Begins
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton has a chance to become the first female nominee from either major party. First, she will be pushed to explain why she wants the job.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton has a chance to become the first female nominee from either major party. First, she will be pushed to explain why she wants the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, the suspense surrounding Hillary Rodham Clinton’s plans to make a second attempt at the White House had little to do with whether, and everything to do with why: What would be her rationale for seeking the presidency?

articles.headline: Mighty Rio Grande Now a Trickle Under Siege
articles.snippet: A region confronts changing weather patterns that have shrunk snowpacks, raised temperatures, spurred evaporation and reduced reservoirs to record lows.
articles.abstract: A region confronts changing weather patterns that have shrunk snowpacks, raised temperatures, spurred evaporation and reduced reservoirs to record lows.
articles.lead_paragraph: FABENS, Tex. — On maps, the mighty Rio Grande meanders 1,900 miles, from southern Colorado’s San Juan Mountains to the Gulf of Mexico. But on the ground, farms and cities drink all but a trickle before it reaches the canal that irrigates Bobby Skov’s farm outside El Paso, hundreds of miles from the gulf.

articles.headline: After 8 Shots in North Charleston, Michael Slager Becomes an Officer Scorned
articles.snippet: Michael T. Slager was just a small-town police officer, but a shooting on April 4 has made him a symbol of law enforcement gone awry.
articles.abstract: Michael T. Slager was just a small-town police officer, but a shooting on April 4 has made him a symbol of law enforcement gone awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Michael T. Slager played cops and robbers as a boy in the Virginia woods, volunteered as an emergency medical technician after high school and earned an associate degree in criminal justice while working full time as a patrolman.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Alan Blinder and Jason Grant

articles.headline: Günter Grass Dies at 87; Writer Pried Open Germany’s Past but Hid His Own
articles.snippet: Mr. Grass was the novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been in the Waffen-SS.
articles.abstract: Mr. Grass was the novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been in the Waffen-SS.
articles.lead_paragraph: Günter Grass, the German novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been a member of the Waffen-SS during World War II, died on Monday in the northern German city of Lübeck, which had been his home for decades. He was 87.

articles.headline: Putin Lifts Ban on Russian Missile Sales to Iran
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin moved swiftly to take advantage of a possible thaw in relations over a potential deal curbing Iran’s nuclear ambitions.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin moved swiftly to take advantage of a possible thaw in relations over a potential deal curbing Iran’s nuclear ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday approved the delivery of a sophisticated air defense missile system to Iran, potentially complicating negotiations on Tehran’s nuclear program and further straining ties with Washington.
